columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to determine the net present value (NPV) of the project.
**Capital budgeting** is the concept of determining the cost of a project or investment.  The difference between the cost and the market value of the investment is called the **net present value**.

We are given the following data:

- The project costs € 10.5 million.
- The project is expected to produce cash flows of € 1.7 million in Year 1.
- The project is expected to produce cash flows of € 2.4 million in Year 2.
- The project is expected to produce cash flows of €3.3 million in Year 3.

Additionally, we are given the following data:
- The current spot exchange rate is € .94/$.
- The current-risk free rate in United States is 2.3%.
- The current-risk free rate in Europe is 1.8%.
The discount rate of the project is 13% which is the cost of capital of the company in the United States. The subsidiary can be sold at the end of three years for an estimate of € 7.9 million.

To determine the NPV, we will use the **home currency approach** of international capital budgeting. In home currency approach, we will convert all the foreign currency into the home currency, and apply the discount rate to determine the NPV.

The formula that will be used in the home currency approach is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{t})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^t\\\
\end{aligned}$$

wherein: 

$E(S_{t})$ = Expected exchange rate in *t* periods

$S_{0}$ = Current spot exchange rate  

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate in foreign country 

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate in the U.S.

First, we will determine the exchange rate in Year 1. Applying the formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{1})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times[ 1+\text{(0.018-0.023)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.005)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times( 0.995)^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times0.995\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{€ 0.9353}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 1 is **€ 0.9353 per $ 1**.

Next, we will determine the exchange rate in Year 2. Applying the formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{2})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times[ 1+\text{(0.018-0.023)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.005)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times( 0.995)^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times0.990\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{€ 0.9306}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 2 is **€ 0.9306 per $ 1**.

Lastly, we will determine the exchange rate in Year 3. Applying the formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{3})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times[ 1+\text{(0.018-0.023)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.005)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times( 0.995)^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{€ 0.94}\times0.9851\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{€ 0.9260}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 3 is **€ 0.9260 per $ 1**.

Next, we will divide the expected cash flow per year by the expected exchange rate to determine the cash flow in U.S. dollars.  To visualize:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash Flow in \$} &= \dfrac{\text{Cash Flow in € }}{\text{Exchange Rate}}\\[10pt]

\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have converted the expected cash flows into dollars. We need to divide it to the discount rate of 13% so we can get the  present value. The formula is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Present Value } &= \dfrac{\text{Cash Flow in \$ }}{\text{(1 + Discount Rate)}^t}\\

\end{aligned}$$

We will now combine the present value for Year 1, Year 2, and Year 3.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Present Value Y1}&&\$ 1,608,495\\
\text{Present Value Y2}&&2,019,720\\
\text{Present Value Y3}&&\underline{~~~~8,382,446}\\
\text{Total Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{\$ 12,010,661}}}\\
\end{array}$$

Lastly, we will subtract the investment cost of $ 11,170,213 from the present value to get the **net present value**.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Total Present Value}&&\$ 12,010,661\\
\text{Cost of Investment}&&\underline{(11,170,213)}\\
\text{Net Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{~~~~~~~\$ 840,448}}}\\
\end{array}$$
As a conclusion, the net present value (NPV) of the project is **$840,448** applying the concept of home currency approach.
